In this study, the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) on vanadium oxide (VO x )-based catalysts was investigated. Using various catalyst supports, VO x /HZSM-5 exhibited the highest MDA activity. In MDA using VO x /HZSM-5, an induction period was observed. Raman spectroscopy and XPS analysis indicated that V2O5 species result in the highly dispersed state by the contact with CH4. X-ray absorption fine structure analysis suggested the formation of VC species. Such structural changes lead to the induction period for the MDA reaction. Based on the effect of the catalyst support and the aromatization reaction of ethylene, we propose a mechanism in which methane forms ethylene on the vanadium catalyst, and ethylene is then aromatized with the aid of the acid sites and micropore structure of HZSM-5. Additionally, the effect of hydrogen co-feeding on the MDA reaction was investigated, which revealed that catalyst deactivation due to coke formation was suppressed in the presence of hydrogen. While natural gas is mainly used as a fuel, it can also serve as an alternative to petroleum for producing basic chemicals such as ethylene (C2H4) and benzene. The principal component of natural gas is methane (CH4), and to transform CH4 into basic chemicals, cleaving the C-H bonds in CH4 and forming C-C bonds are crucial. However, because CH4 has the highest C-H bond dissociation energy among all alkanes, its activation and subsequent C-C bond formation are not straightforward [1–3]. The dehydrogenative conversion of CH4 has been investigated, and numerous catalysts that facilitate this reaction have been reported [4–12]. CH4 dehydroaromatization (MDA) is a representative dehydrogenative conversion process. Several HZSM-5-supported transition-metal catalysts have been reported to be effective against MDA. Mo/HZSM-5 is a well-known catalyst that promotes MDA. Since the first report on MDA using Mo/HZSM-5 in 1993 [13], the development of MDA catalysts based on Mo/HZSM-5 has been pursued [14–19]. Molybdenum carbide species (MoC x ), which are believed to form upon the reduction of MoO x in contact with CH4, are considered the active sites for MDA [15,18,20]. Among others, for example, Fe/HZSM-5 has shown that iron carbide species and partially reduced Fe suboxides serve as active sites for MDA [21]. Another example is Co/HZSM-5, in which single-atom Co2+ anchored on the acid sites of the zeolite is believed to be the active site [22]. In 1998, Lunsford et al. reported that among various M/HZSM-5 catalysts (M=Mo, Fe, V, W, and Cr), VO x /HZSM-5 exhibited moderate MDA activity. A maximum CH4 conversion of 3% was achieved at 750°C with a benzene selectivity of approximately 30% [23]. Based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements, they proposed that V2O3, formed from the reduction of V2O5 upon contact with CH4, acts as an active site for MDA [24]. However, detailed investigations on MDA over VO x /HZSM-5 were not conducted in their studies, and since the studies by Lunsford et al., no other research has been reported on MDA using VO x /HZSM-5, leaving its catalytic performance and active site structure unclear. Kiani et al. also pointed out that only a limited number of studies have reported on the nature of the VO x site in supported VO x /HZSM-5 catalysts during MDA and the necessity for research on VO x /HZSM-5 as an MDA catalyst [25]; however, such studies have not been conducted. In this study, we examined the MDA reaction using VO x /HZSM-5 catalyst. Using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), XPS, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses, we analyzed the structural change in VO x species during MDA. Additionally, it has been reported that HZSM-5 plays a crucial role in the formation of aromatics in MDA on HZSM-5-supported transition-metal catalysts [26–28]. However, the role of HZSM-5 in VOx/HZSM-5 has not yet been investigated; therefore, this study elucidates the effect of HZSM-5 on the MDA over VO x /HZSM-5. Based on these findings, a reaction mechanism for MDA over VO x /HZSM-5 is proposed. Finally, we demonstrate the suppression of catalyst deactivation by co-feeding H2 into the CH4 stream. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3; Kanto Chemical Co., Inc.), ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3; Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd.), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS; Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH; Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.), SiO2 (CAB-O-SIL M-5; Cabot Corp.), SiO2·Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-2; Catalysis Society of Japan), HZSM-5 (HSZ-822, HSZ-840, and HSZ-890; Tosoh Corp.), mordenite (JRC-Z-HM20; Catalysis Society of Japan), and NaBEA-25 (JRC-Z-B25; Catalysis Society of Japan) were used as received. For the preparation of silicalite-1, the hydrothermal synthesis method reported in the literature was followed [29]. A mixture of TEOS (10.4 mL), TPOAH (4.48 mL), and water (8.37 mL) was prepared in a 100 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was stirred for 3 h at 50°C, followed by aging at 170°C for 72 h in a Teflon autoclave. The resultant solid was then filtered, washed with deionized water, dried overnight at 110°C, and calcined at 500°C for 2 h to obtain silicalite-1. Because JRC-Z-B25 (NaBEA-25) contains 0.15 wt% Na, a proton-exchange treatment was carried out to obtain HBEA, as described in the literature [30]. A 200 mL beaker was filled with a 1 M NH4NO3 aqueous solution, to which 6 g of JRC-Z-B25 was added. The mixture was stirred at 80°C for 24 h, filtered, and the resultant solid dried overnight at 110°C. The prepared samples were calcined at 550°C for 3.5 h to obtain HBEA. 2.2 Preparation of the VOx/HZSM-5 catalysts Supported VO x catalysts were prepared using an impregnation method. The vanadium loading was 3 wt%. First, NH4VO3 was dissolved in 70 mL deionized water. Under stirring, various supports were added to the solution, and water was evaporated on a hot plate. The obtained solid was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500°C for 2 h. The catalyst was then pelletized into discs approximately 20 mm in diameter and 2 mm in thickness using a compaction press at a pressure of 400 kg cm−2 for 10 min. Finally, the discs were ground using an agate mortar and the crushed powder was sieved to particle sizes between 355 and 710 µm. 2.3 MDA reactions A quartz reactor was packed with 50 mg of quartz wool and 0.50 g of the catalyst. The reactor was purged with Ar at 40 mL min−1, and the temperature was increased to 750°C. After 10 min at 750°C, CH4 was introduced at 20 mL min−1 and the outlet gas was analyzed. The flow rate of the outlet gas was measured using a soap-film flowmeter. The charge correction was performed by referencing the binding energy of C 1 s at 284.6 eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 MDA on VOx/HZSM-5 Fig. 1 shows the results of MDA on HZSM-5 and VO x /HZSM-5. C2 hydrocarbons (ethane and ethylene), C3 hydrocarbons (propane and propylene), aromatics (benzene, toluene, and naphthalene), and H2 were detected as the products. Because of their low selectivity for C3 hydrocarbons (∼ 1%), they were not the focus of this study. CH4 conversion as a function of time on stream is shown in Fig. 1a. For VO x /HZSM-5, a rapid increase in CH4 conversion was observed during the initial stage of the reaction, reaching a peak of 5% at 40 min. Subsequently, the CH4 conversion gradually declined and remained at approximately 3% after 280 min. In contrast, CH4 conversion was almost 0% when HZSM-5 was used as the catalyst, suggesting that VO x plays a crucial role in the activation of CH4 molecules. For the aromatics selectivity of VO x /HZSM-5 (Fig. 1b), a profile similar to that of CH4 conversion was observed, and the maximum aromatics selectivity reached 66%. The selectivity for C2 hydrocarbons increased with time on stream, reaching 15% at 280 min (Fig. 1c). The total selectivity of the products for MDA is shown in Fig. 1d. The primary products of C2 and the aromatic components were ethylene and benzene, respectively. The total selectivity for hydrocarbons was 67%, indicating that VO x /HZSM-5 can convert CH4 into valuable compounds. At the initial stage of the reaction, a sharp increase in the catalytic activity was observed, which can be attributed to the induction period of MDA on VO x /HZSM-5. The induction period suggests a structural change in the VO x /HZSM-5 catalyst due to the CH4 contact. It has been reported that in MDA using Mo/HZSM-5, MO x is converted into MoC x by contact with CH4, resulting in an induction period [31]. Thus, it is possible that a similar structural change occurred in the VO x /HZSM-5. This point will be discussed in detail later in this study. The characterization of VO x /HZSM-5 was conducted before and after the MDA reaction. Fig. 2a shows the XRD patterns of HZSM-5, fresh VO x /HZSM-5, and spent VO x /HZSM-5. The XRD patterns of fresh VO x /HZSM-5 and spent VO x /HZSM-5 were the same as those of HZSM-5, indicating that the structure of HZSM-5 remained intact during MDA reactions. Peaks due to VO x species could not be identified by the XRD analysis. The Raman spectra of HZSM-5, fresh VO x /HZSM-5, and spent VO x /HZSM-5 are shown in Fig. 2b. While no distinct peaks were identified for HZSM-5, several peaks attributed to V2O5 were observed for fresh VO x /HZSM-5 [32], and the peaks disappeared after 10 min of reaction. The change in the Raman spectra suggests that the V2O5 structure present in the fresh catalyst was drastically changed by the contact with CH4. Fig. 2c shows the V 2p3/2 XPS spectra of fresh VO x /HZSM-5 and spent VO x /HZSM-5. Peaks attributable to V5+ species at 517.3 eV and V4+ species at 516.3 eV were detected for fresh VO x /HZSM-5 [24]. Given the presence of V2O5, as indicated by the Raman spectra of the fresh catalyst, the V5+ species identified by XPS were considered to originate from V2O5. In the catalyst after 10 min of MDA reaction, a new peak was observed at 518.5 eV. It has been reported that the peak appearing at higher binding energies can be attributed to highly dispersed V5+ species interacting with the catalyst supports [33,34]. Raman spectroscopy indicates the disappearance of V2O5 upon the initiation of the MDA reaction. Considering the XPS analysis and Raman spectroscopy, it is suggested that contact with CH4 leads to the drastic structural change of V2O5 species into a highly dispersed vanadium state. In the Raman spectra, new peaks around 1380 cm−1 and 1597 cm−1 appeared after the reaction at 280 min, which were attributed to the D and G bands of the carbons [35]. In the MDA reaction, coke is formed from CH4 (CH4 → C + 2 H2) as well as hydrocarbon products; thus, peaks due to coke were detected after the reaction. Coke formation was confirmed using TG analysis. The TG profiles of the spent VO x /HZSM-5 are shown in Fig. 2d. A weight loss of 7% was observed between 350 °C and 650 °C, which can be attributed to the combustion of coke. Coke possibly covers the catalytically active sites, which is the reason for the gradual decrease in CH4 conversion observed in Fig. 1a. Fig. 3 shows the V K-edge XANES spectra of the VO x /HZSM-5 catalysts and reference samples. VO x /HZSM-5 before the reaction exhibited an XANES spectrum similar to that of V2O5. As suggested by the Raman spectrum, a V2O5 structure was formed in the catalyst prior to CH4 contact. As the MDA reaction proceeded, the shapes of the XANES spectra changed; the pre-edge became smaller. Compared with the reference samples, the spectrum of the spent catalysts was similar to that of either VC or V2O3. The pre-edge of V2O3 was very small, but the pre-edge of the spent catalyst was not as small. On the other hand, the pre-edge of VC is larger than that of V2O3. Additionally, considering the extensive research on Mo/HZSM-5, in which the formation of MoC x species is presumed, it is likely that vanadium carbide species were formed in VO x /HZSM-5 upon contact with CH4. 3.2 Role of catalyst supports in MDA reaction on VOx catalysts The effect of the catalyst support on the MDA reaction was investigated using VO x /HZSM-5, VO x /SiO2, VO x /SiO2-Al2O3, and VO x /silicalite-1. Fig. 4a shows the CH4 conversion as a function of time on stream for each catalyst. Although all catalysts converted CH4, the CH4 conversion depended on the type of support. The trend in CH4 conversion is as follows: VO x /HZSM-5 > VO x /SiO2 > VO x /SiO2-Al2O3 > VO x /silicalite-1. Figs. 4b and c show the selectivities for aromatics and C2 hydrocarbons, respectively. VO x /HZSM-5 reached up to 60% aromatics selectivity, significantly outperforming VO x /SiO2, VO x /SiO2-Al2O3, and VO x /silicalite-1, all of which achieved aromatics selectivity of less than 20%. The C2 selectivity also depended on the type of support, but the difference in C2 selectivity between the catalysts was small. The C2 selectivity remained within the range of 5–20%, indicating that the effect of the support on C2 formation was not as evident as that on aromatics formation. The total product selectivity for the MDA reactions is shown in Fig. 4d. VO x /HZSM-5 achieved the highest selectivity for hydrocarbons (67%), whereas the other catalysts showed approximately 20% hydrocarbon selectivity and mainly formed coke. The results shown in Fig. 4 indicate that the type of support profoundly affected MDA; specifically, VO x /HZSM-5 exhibited superior performance in the production of aromatics. HZSM-5 is an aluminosilicate zeolite with micropore (about 5 Å) and acid sites. Compared with HZSM-5, SiO2 lacked both acid sites and micropores, SiO2-Al2O3 had acid sites but no micropores, and silicalite-1 had a similar micropore to HZSM-5 but no acid sites. Given the properties of the supports, the lower aromatics selectivity of all supports except HZSM-5 suggests that both the acidity and micropore structure of HZSM-5 play important roles in the production of aromatics. Hence, hereafter, we will investigate the effects of the acidic properties and micropores on the MDA reaction in detail. The effect of acidic properties of HZSM-5 on the MDA reaction was investigated using different types of HZSM-5 (HSZ-822; SiO2/Al2O3 = 24, HSZ-840; SiO2/Al2O3 = 40, and HSZ-890; SiO2/Al2O3 = 1500). The results of this reaction are shown in Fig. 5. VO x /HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3= 24) achieved the highest CH4 conversion, and as the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio increased, CH4 conversion decreased. It should be noted that the aromatics selectivity showed the same trend as CH4 conversion, that is, the aromatics selectivity decreased as the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio in VO x /HZSM-5 decreased. The C2 selectivity was lower than the aromatics selectivity and hardly affected by the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. The results suggest that the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, which corresponds to the number of acid sites in HZSM-5, affects the aromatics production in the MDA reaction. HZSM-5, which had a higher number of acid sites, was found to be effective for aromatics formation. In Mo/HZSM-5, CH4 is activated on MoC x , and the formed C2 hydrocarbons are subjected to oligomerization on the Brønsted acid sites of the zeolite to form benzene and naphthalene [16]. Similar to the Mo/HZSM-5, it was found that the role of HZSM-5 in VO x /HZSM-5 is to facilitate the aromatization of C2 hydrocarbons. As described above, the acidic sites of HZSM-5 were involved in the formation of aromatics. Previous studies have suggested that not only the acidic properties of zeolites, but also their micropores influence the formation of aromatics in MDA reactions on Mo/HZSM-5 [28,36]. To verify whether a similar mechanism was established in the case of VO x /HZSM-5, we investigated the effect of zeolite pore structure on the MDA reaction using different types of zeolites: MOR, HBEA, and HZSM-5. Note that the MOR, HBEA, and HZSM-5 used here possess similar acidic properties because their SiO2/Al2O3 ratios are similar to those of MOR (SiO2/Al2O3=20), HBEA (SiO2/Al2O3=25), and HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3=24). The results are shown in Fig. 6. VO x /HZSM-5 showed the highest CH4 conversion (3–5%), followed by VO x /HBEA (3–3.5%) and VO x /MOR (1.5–3%). The C2 selectivity was consistently below 20% for all the catalysts. In contrast, aromatics selectivity varied significantly depending on the type of zeolite. VO x /HZSM-5 demonstrated a high aromatics selectivity of 40–60%, whereas VO x /HBEA was below 20%, and VO x /MOR produced almost no aromatics. Considering that HZSM-5, HBEA, and MOR possess almost the same SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, the aromatics selectivity depends on the type of zeolite, suggesting that the pore structure of the zeolite also has a strong influence on the formation of aromatics. Previous research on MDA with Mo-based catalysts found that zeolites with pore sizes close to the size of benzene molecules (about 6 Å) effectively produced aromatics [28]. Given the pore sizes of the zeolites used in this study (HZSM-5: 0.54–0.56 nm, HBEA: 0.55–0.70 nm, and MOR: 0.65–0.70 nm), HZSM-5 is believed to have been an effective catalyst support for VO x in producing aromatics, because its pore size is similar to that of benzene molecules. These findings suggest a mechanism wherein CH4 initially couples with V species to produce C2 hydrocarbons, which subsequently form aromatics with the aid of HZSM-5. To validate this mechanism, we examined the aromatization of C2 hydrocarbons over zeolites. 3.3 Aromatization reaction of C2H4 We examined the aromatization of C2H4 over HZSM-5, HBEA, and MOR. Note that only zeolites were used for the reaction, that is VO x was not included. The results are shown in Fig. 7. The aromatization of C2H4 proceeded and the type of zeolite influenced the aromatization reaction. The C2H4 conversion ranged from 30% to 80%, depending on the type of zeolite used. HZSM-5 exhibited the highest benzene selectivity, whereas benzene selectivity of HBEA and MOR was lower. At 100 min, the benzene selectivity decreased in the following order: HZSM-5 (33%) > HBEA (13%) > MOR (6%). As shown in Fig. 6, the aromatics selectivity for MDA on VO x /zeolite was as follows: VO x /HZSM-5 > VO x /HBEA > VO x /MOR. The benzene selectivity from C2H4 using zeolites showed the same trend as the aromatics selectivity from CH4 using VO x /zeolites, implying that zeolites play an important role in aromatization reactions. The MDA reaction was conducted using a physical mixture of VO x /SiO2 and HZSM-5, hereafter referred to as VO x /SiO2+HZSM-5 ( Fig. 8). As previously shown (Fig. 1), HZSM-5 alone achieved nearly 0% CH4 conversion, indicating that HZSM-5 could not activate the CH4 molecules. Notably, VO x /SiO2+HZSM-5 achieved higher CH4 conversion than VO x /SiO2 alone, suggesting that HZSM-5 contributed to the reaction. Although the selectivities for C2 hydrocarbons were similar for both catalysts, the selectivity for aromatics significantly increased in the presence of HZSM-5; indeed, the addition of HZSM-5 doubled the aromatics selectivity. This indicates that HZSM-5 enhances the aromatization of C2 hydrocarbons generated on VO x /SiO2. Based on these results, we proposed a mechanism for the MDA reaction using the VO x /HZSM-5 catalyst. In the fresh catalyst, V2O5 was present on the HZSM-5. Upon contact with CH4, V2O5 transforms into VC x species, which serve as active sites for the coupling of CH4 to produce C2 hydrocarbons, predominantly C2H4. The formed C2H4 was then converted into aromatics, facilitated by the acidic sites and micropores of HZSM-5. 3.4 Effect of H2 co-feeding As discussed thus far, although the VO x /HZSM-5 catalyst is effective for the MDA reaction, as shown by the total product selectivity, it also generates coke in addition to hydrocarbons. Coke formation was also demonstrated using Raman spectroscopy and TG analysis. It is believed that the gradual decrease in the production of aromatics during the MDA reaction is due to coke formation. In CH4 conversion using Mo/HZSM-5 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, H2 co-feeding mitigates catalyst deactivation because coke deposition is suppressed [10,37–40]. Therefore, we examined the effect of H2 co-feeding on the MDA reaction using the VO x /HZSM-5 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9a, CH4 conversion decreased with increasing H2 co-feeding. This trend suggests that dehydrogenative conversion of CH4 is inhibited in the presence of H2. Under the condition of CH4-only feeding, there was a decline in CH4 conversion over time on stream. However, when co-fed with H2, the decline in CH4 conversion was more gradual, indicating that H2 co-feeding suppressed the catalyst deactivation. Aromatics selectivity exhibited a gradual decline under CH4-only feeding (Fig. 9b). In contrast, co-feeding H2 at 1 or 0.5 mL min−1 stabilized the aromatics selectivity, consistently maintaining a high selectivity level of 70–80%. However, at a co-feed rate of 2 mL min−1, aromatics selectivity decreased significantly. The C2 selectivity remained largely consistent regardless of H2 co-feeding, with a noticeable increase observed at a co-feed rate of 2 mL min−1 (Fig. 9c). Overall, the presence of H2 at 1 mL min−1 reduced coke formation, thereby boosting the selectivity towards both aromatics and C2H4 (Fig. 9d). Fig. 10 shows the TG profiles of the spent catalysts. The observed weight loss at 400–600℃ can be attributed to the combustion of the coke deposited on the catalysts. The TG profile indicates that the weight loss due to coke combustion was reduced by the H2 co-feed. This suggests that the H2 co-feed inhibits excessive CH4 dehydrogenation, which can lead to coke formation, thereby limiting catalyst deactivation. Stabilization of aromatics selectivity and suppression of coke deposition due to H2 co-feeding were also observed in the MDA reaction at a higher temperature (800°C). To confirm that H2 co-feeding did not influence the aromatization mechanism, we conducted an aromatization reaction of C2H4 in the presence of H2 (1 and 2.5 mL min−1). The results are shown in Fig. 11. C2H4 conversion slightly decreased at 2.5 mL min−1 of H2. Aromatics selectivity was lower with 2.5 mL min−1 of H2, suggesting that H2 co-feeding suppressed the aromatization of C2H4. The results can be understood because the aromatization of C2H4 is a dehydrogenation process. Therefore, it can be understood that H2 co-feeding did not enhance the aromatization of C2H4. These findings indicate that the stable aromatics selectivity under H2 co-feeding in MDA is not due to the direct influence of H2 on the reaction mechanism, but rather to the prevention of coke deposition on the catalytic active sites. 4 Conclusions While there has been extensive research on MDA reactions using HZSM-5-supported transition metals, there have been very few studies on VO x /HZSM-5. This study focused on the characteristics of the MDA reaction in VO x /HZSM-5 and the structural analysis of VO x species. VO x /HZSM-5 catalyzed the MDA reaction, demonstrating an aromatics selectivity of approximately 50%. Catalyst activity gradually decreased, and TG analysis and Raman spectroscopy suggested that coke deposition on the catalyst contributed to the decline in activity. The XRD patterns, Raman spectra, and XPS analysis revealed that V2O5 species were formed on the catalyst before the reaction, and the contact of CH4 with the V2O5 results in the highly dispersed V5+ species interacting with HZSM-5 supports. The contact of CH4 leading to the high dispersion of the active sites is a characteristic behavior for MDA on VO x /HZSM-5. Additionally, the XAFS analysis showed the formation of V2O5 species before the reaction and suggested the formation of VC species during the MDA reaction. It was found that this structural change in the V2O5 species upon contact with CH4 is responsible for the induction period of the MDA reaction. The role of the HZSM-5 support is similar to that of previously reported catalysts, where C2H4 produced by the catalysis of the transition metal is aromatized with the aid of HZSM-5. The VO x /HZSM-5 catalysts were gradually deactivated by coke, but co-feeding H2 with CH4 suppressed coke deposition and stabilized aromatics selectivity. H2 co-feeding did not affect the aromatization reaction mechanism but only suppressed coke formation on VO x /HZSM-5. Although the catalytic function of VO x /HZSM-5 in MDA was poorly understood, this study has elucidated its catalytic activity, reaction mechanism, and structure of V species. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) on vanadium oxide (VO x )-based catalysts was investigated. Using various catalyst supports, VO x /HZSM-5 exhibited the highest MDA activity. In MDA using VO x /HZSM-5, an induction period was observed. Raman spectroscopy and XPS analysis indicated that V2O5 species result in the highly dispersed state by the contact with CH4. X-ray absorption fine structure analysis suggested the formation of VC species. Such structural changes lead to the induction period for the MDA reaction. Based on the effect of the catalyst support and the aromatization reaction of ethylene, we propose a mechanism in which methane forms ethylene on the vanadium catalyst, and ethylene is then aromatized with the aid of the acid sites and micropore structure of HZSM-5. Additionally, the effect of hydrogen co-feeding on the MDA reaction was investigated, which revealed that catalyst deactivation due to coke formation was suppressed in the presence of hydrogen.
coredata.dc:title: Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) on VO x /HZSM-5 catalysts
